message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can lead to rebound congestion, where the decongestant actually causes congestion rather than relieving it. Epistaxis, permanent loss of smell, and persistent nasal crusting are all potential side effects of chronic use of nasal decongestants but are less likely than rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can lead to rebound congestion, where the nasal passages become congested and inflamed even after the medication is stopped. Epistaxis, permanent loss of smell, and persistent nasal crusting are possible complications of long-term use but are less likely than rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants may lead to rebound congestion and persistent nasal congestion, but not epistaxis, permanent loss of smell or persistent nasal crusting.

We refer to Mayo Clinic for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can result in rebound congestion or persistent congestion, where the medication stops working and the patient becomes addicted to it. Epistaxis or nosebleeds may occur but are not a likely sequela of chronic use. Permanent loss of smell and persistent nasal crusting are not common complications of chronic use of topical nasal decongestants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Topical nasal decongestants should not be used for more than 3 days as they can lead to rebound congestion, which can persist even after discontinuing the medication. Epistaxis can occur but is less likely than persistent congestion. Permanent loss of smell and persistent nasal crusting are not typical sequelae of chronic use of topical nasal decongestants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can lead to rebound congestion or persistent nasal congestion, which is the most likely sequela in this case. Epistaxis is a potential complication of intranasal vasoconstrictors, but it is not specific to chronic use. Permanent loss of smell and persistent nasal crusting are not common complications of intranasal vasoconstrictors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can result in rebound congestion or rhinitis medicamentosa, leading to persistent congestion. Epistaxis and nasal crusting can also occur, but are less likely than persistent congestion. Permanent loss of smell is not a common sequela of topical nasal decongestant use.

Epistaxis is also possible, but less likely. Permanent loss of smell and persistent nasal crusting are not commonly associated with chronic use of topical nasal decongestants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can cause rebound congestion, leading to persistent congestion. Epistaxis can occur with moderate to severe use, but it's not a likely sequela. Permanent loss of smell and persistent nasal crusting are not associated with the chronic use of topical nasal decongestants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Chronic use of topical nasal decongestants can lead to rebound congestion, where the patient has persistent congestion even after discontinuing the medication. Epistaxis and nasal crusting are also possible side effects but are not as likely as rebound congestion. Permanent loss of smell is a rare complication of intranasal corticosteroids, not vasoconstrictors.
